listDisplay.primary: Susanoo-no-Mikoto - The Tempestuous God of Storms and Sea
listDisplay.secondary: Storm God, Hero of Izumo, Slayer of Yamata no Orochi

subtitle: The Tempestuous God of Storms and Sea

gridDisplay.subtitle: The Tempestuous God of Storms and Sea

hoverInfo.quick: Wild storm god who slew the eight-headed dragon and won Kusanagi sword

gridDisplay.title: Susanoo-no-Mikoto

name: Susanoo-no-Mikoto

narratives.title: Birth and Exile from Heaven
narratives.summary: Born from Izanagi's nose during purification after fleeing Yomi. Assigned to rule the seas but instead wept for his mother Izanami. His weeping caused devastation, and he was eventually exiled to the underworld.
narratives.significance: Shows his connection to the primordial and his grief-driven nature

narratives.title: The Conflict with Amaterasu
narratives.summary: Susanoo visited heaven claiming good intentions but proceeded to commit horrific acts: destroying rice paddies, defecating in Amaterasu's hall, and throwing a flayed horse into her weaving hall, killing one of her attendants. These outrages caused Amaterasu to hide in the Heavenly Rock Cave, plunging the world into darkness.
narratives.significance: His wild nature in opposition to cosmic order; leads to his expulsion

narratives.title: Slaying Yamata no Orochi
narratives.summary: Wandering after his exile, Susanoo encountered an elderly couple weeping because their daughter Kushinadahime would be devoured by the eight-headed, eight-tailed dragon Yamata no Orochi. Susanoo offered to slay the beast in exchange for her hand in marriage. He had eight vats of sake prepared, one for each head. When the dragon drank itself unconscious, Susanoo struck, severing all eight heads. Within its tail he discovered the divine sword Kusanagi-no-Tsurugi.
narratives.significance: Transformation from destroyer to hero; origin of one of the Three Sacred Treasures

narratives.title: The First Poetry
narratives.summary: After marrying Kushinadahime and settling in Izumo, Susanoo composed the first Japanese poem: 'Yakumo tatsu / Izumo yaegaki / Tsuma-gomi ni / Yaegaki tsukuru / Sono yaegaki wo' (Rising clouds form / Izumo's many-layered fence / To shelter my bride / I build many-layered fences / Ah, those many-layered fences!).
narratives.significance: Marks him as father of Japanese poetry and establisher of domestic civilization

narratives.title: Testing Okuninushi
narratives.summary: In some accounts, Susanoo appears as lord of the underworld who tests his descendant/future son-in-law Okuninushi through impossible trials before ultimately blessing his marriage to his daughter Suseri-hime.
narratives.significance: Role as divine tester and ancestor of nation-building lineage

search.searchableText: susanoo-no-mikoto storm god sea izumo yamata no orochi kusanagi dragon slayer

description: Susanoo-no-Mikoto is the powerful storm god of Japanese mythology, a deity of fierce contrasts. Born from the purification of Izanagi, he was exiled from heaven for his destructive behavior toward Amaterasu, yet redeemed himself by slaying the monstrous eight-headed dragon Yamata no Orochi and discovering the legendary sword Kusanagi within its tail.

historicalContext.historicalPeriod: Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE)
historicalContext.sourceText: Kojiki - Books 1-2: Storm god and hero narrative

shrineSites.name: Izumo Taisha
shrineSites.significance: Primary shrine; associated with Susanoo's dragon-slaying and marriage to Kushinadahime
shrineSites.notes: Second most important shrine after Ise Grand Shrine in Shinto hierarchy

shrineSites.name: Yasaka Shrine (Gion Shrine)
shrineSites.significance: Major shrine dedicated to Susanoo as Gozu Tenno, center of Gion Matsuri

shrineSites.name: Kumano Nachi Taisha
shrineSites.significance: Kumano shrine complex - Susanoo associated with mountain spirituality

shrineSites.name: Atsuta Shrine
shrineSites.significance: Houses the Kusanagi-no-Tsurugi, the sacred sword found by Susanoo

shrineSites.name: Susa Shrine
shrineSites.significance: Founded at the location where Susanoo built his palace after marriage

festivalAssociations.name: Gion Matsuri
festivalAssociations.significance: One of Japan's three greatest festivals, honoring Susanoo as plague-preventing deity Gozu Tenno

festivalAssociations.name: Izumo Matsuri
festivalAssociations.significance: Honors Susanoo and the gathering of kami

buddhistEquivalents.connection: Honji suijaku - Susanoo as manifestation of Buddhist plague-preventing deity
buddhistEquivalents.significance: Plague prevention deity fusion, central to Gion Matsuri

imperialConnections.kusanagi: One of Three Sacred Treasures (Imperial Regalia)
imperialConnections.heroNarrative: Hero archetype - demon-slaying legitimizes divine order

historicalNotes: Likely reflects historical conflicts: Yamato vs Izumo peoples
Chaos deity subdued: represents bringing wild nature under divine law
Storm god archetype across Indo-European traditions (comparison: Thor, Zeus, Indra)

practices: Prayers for protection from storms and natural disasters
Purification rituals during Gion Matsuri to prevent plague
Offerings at shrines for agricultural blessing (rain for crops)
Veneration as heroic protector and dragon-slayer

sacredObjects.name: Kusanagi-no-Tsurugi
sacredObjects.description: The 'Grass-Cutting Sword' found in Yamata no Orochi's tail, one of Three Imperial Treasures

sacredObjects.name: Totsuka-no-Tsurugi
sacredObjects.description: The Ten-Span Sword used to slay the dragon

sacredObjects.name: Sake Vats
sacredObjects.description: The eight vats of sake used to intoxicate the dragon

sacredPlants: Rice (destroyed in his wild phase, protected in his heroic phase)

primary.title: Kojiki
primary.author: O no Yasumaro
primary.description: Record of Ancient Matters - most complete Susanoo narrative

primary.title: Nihon Shoki
primary.author: Prince Toneri et al.
primary.description: Chronicles of Japan - variant accounts of Susanoo myths

primary.title: Izumo Fudoki
primary.author: Various
primary.description: Regional Chronicles of Izumo - local Susanoo traditions

father.name: Izanagi-no-Mikoto
father.relationship: Born from his nose during purification

mother.name: Izanami-no-Mikoto
mother.relationship: Longed for, though born after her death

siblings.name: Amaterasu-Omikami
siblings.relationship: Sun Goddess, elder sister, born from left eye

siblings.name: Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto
siblings.relationship: Moon God, elder brother, born from right eye

spouses.name: Kushinadahime
spouses.note: The princess he saved from Yamata no Orochi

descendants.name: Okuninushi
descendants.note: Great land master, either son or sixth-generation descendant

divineRelationships.rival: Amaterasu - his wild nature opposed her ordered brilliance
divineRelationships.tested: Okuninushi - whom he subjected to deadly trials
divineRelationships.protected: Kushinadahime - the princess he saved and married

symbolism.archetype: Storm God - wild nature power, redeemed hero, civilization bringer

typologicalConnections.observation: Susanoo as storm god parallels storm theophany in Scripture (Psalm 29, Job 38).
typologicalConnections.distinction: The God of Scripture commands storms (Mark 4:39); Susanoo is storm personified.

typologicalConnections.observation: Susanoo's slaying of Yamata-no-Orochi parallels dragon-slaying myths and Revelation's dragon imagery (Revelation 12).
typologicalConnections.distinction: Christ's victory over the dragon/Satan is cosmic and definitive; Susanoo's is localized heroic myth.

scholarlyEnrichment.methodology: Comparative religion from Christian scholarly perspective, incorporating patristic sources and typological analysis
